vocabulary.thai: พี่ครับ / พี่คะ
vocabulary.explanation: The most practical way to get a waiter's attention. พี่ (Pee) means 'older sibling' and is a common, respectful way to address service staff. Men say ครับ (khrap), women say ค่ะ (kha).
vocabulary.example_sentence: พี่ (Pee - 'staff') ครับ (khrap - polite particle), สั่งอาหาร (sang ahaan - 'order food') ได้ไหม (dai mai - 'can I')? - Excuse me, can I order?

vocabulary.explanation: The standard polite way to say thank you.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอบคุณ (Khob khun - 'thank you') ค่ะ (kha - polite particle). - Thank you.

vocabulary.explanation: Use this to confirm something, like when a waiter repeats your order back to you.
vocabulary.example_sentence: A: กาแฟเย็น (kafae yen - 'iced coffee') นะครับ (na khrap)? B: ใช่ (Chai - 'yes') ครับ (khrap). - A: Iced coffee, right? B: Yes, that's right.

vocabulary.explanation: A culturally essential phrase. Use it if they bring the wrong thing but you don't mind, or to say 'you're welcome'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: A: ขอโทษ (Kaw thot - 'sorry'). B: ไม่เป็นไร (Mai pen rai - 'it's okay') ครับ (khrap). - A: Sorry. B: It's okay.

vocabulary.explanation: A critical phrase for any beginner. ไม่ (Mai) is 'not'. เข้าใจ (khao jai) means 'to understand' (literally 'enter heart').
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอโทษ (Kaw thot - 'sorry') ครับ (khrap), ผม (phom - 'I') ไม่เข้าใจ (mai khao jai - 'don't understand'). - Sorry, I don't understand.

vocabulary.explanation: The most common verb for ordering. It's direct but standard in this context. Follow it with the item you want.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll take') ผัดไทย (pad thai) ครับ (khrap - polite particle). - I'll take the Pad Thai.

vocabulary.explanation: A slightly softer, more polite way to ask for things. Means 'to request' or 'may I have'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอ (Kaw - 'may I have') น้ำเปล่า (naam plao - 'water') หนึ่ง (nueng - 'one') ขวด (khuat - 'bottle'). - May I have one bottle of water?

vocabulary.explanation: Your best friend at a street food stall. Just point at what you want and say this.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll take') อันนี้ (an nee - 'this one') ค่ะ (kha - polite particle). - I'll take this one.

vocabulary.thai: ขอเมนูหน่อย
vocabulary.explanation: ขอ (Kaw) is 'may I have', เมนู (menu) is from English, and หน่อย (noi) makes it a polite request.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอเมนูหน่อย (Kaw menu noi - 'menu, please') ครับ (khrap - polite particle). - May I have the menu, please?

vocabulary.thai: อันนี้คืออะไร
vocabulary.explanation: Essential for pointing at food in markets. อันนี้ (An nee) is 'this one', คือ (kue) is 'is', อะไร (arai) is 'what'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: อันนี้คืออะไร (An nee kue arai - 'what is this') ครับ (khrap)? - What is this?

vocabulary.thai: มีอะไรแนะนำไหม
vocabulary.explanation: มี (Mee) is 'is there', อะไร (arai) is 'what', แนะนำ (nae nam) is 'recommend', and ไหม (mai) makes it a question.
vocabulary.example_sentence: มีอะไรแนะนำไหม (mee arai nae nam mai - 'what do you recommend') ครับ (khrap - polite particle)? - Do you have any recommendations?

vocabulary.explanation: A simple question to ask before ordering something you're unsure about.
vocabulary.example_sentence: แกง (Gaeng - 'curry') นี้ (nee - 'this') เผ็ดไหม (phet mai - 'is it spicy')? - Is this curry spicy?

vocabulary.explanation: กิน (Gin) is 'eat', ที่นี่ (tee nee) is 'here'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: กินที่นี่ (Gin tee nee - 'eat here') ครับ (khrap - polite particle). - For here, please.

vocabulary.explanation: Literally means 'return home'. This is the standard phrase for a takeaway order.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll take') สอง (song - 'two') ชุด (chut - 'sets'), กลับบ้าน (glap baan - 'to go'). - I'll take two sets to go.

vocabulary.explanation: The most important phrase for many travelers. ไม่ (Mai) means 'not' and เผ็ด (phet) means 'spicy'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอ (Kaw - 'I'd like') ส้มตำ (som tam) ไม่เผ็ด (mai phet - 'not spicy'). - I'd like papaya salad, not spicy.

vocabulary.explanation: For when you want some heat, but not the full Thai level. เผ็ด (Phet) is 'spicy', น้อย (noi) is 'a little'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll take') ต้มยำ (tom yum) เผ็ดน้อย (phet noi - 'a little spicy'). - I'll take the Tom Yum, a little spicy.

vocabulary.explanation: Crucial for ordering drinks. หวาน (Waan) is 'sweet', น้อย (noi) is 'a little'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll have') ชาไทย (cha thai - 'Thai tea') หวานน้อย (waan noi - 'less sweet'). - I'll have a Thai tea, less sweet.

vocabulary.explanation: A direct way to refuse something. Use this before an ingredient name.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ไม่เอา (Mai ao - 'I don't want') ผักชี (pak chee - 'coriander'). - I don't want coriander.

vocabulary.explanation: Means 'don't put in'. It's very useful for specific ingredients.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอ (Kaw - 'I'd like') ก๋วยเตี๋ยว (guay tiao - 'noodle soup'), ไม่ใส่ (mai sai - 'don't add') ถั่วงอก (tua ngok - 'bean sprouts'). - I'd like noodle soup, don't add bean sprouts.

vocabulary.explanation: Means 'special', but in a food context, it means 'extra'. Follow it with the ingredient you want more of.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอ (Kaw - 'I'd like') ไข่เจียว (kai jiao - 'omelette') พิเศษ (piset - 'extra') หมูสับ (moo sap - 'minced pork'). - I'd like an omelette with extra minced pork.

vocabulary.explanation: A fundamental concept for ordering at simple eateries. It means to serve a stir-fried dish over a plate of rice.
vocabulary.example_sentence: เอา (Ao - 'I'll have') ผัดกะเพรา (pad krapao) ราดข้าว (raat khao - 'on top of rice'). - I'll have Pad Krapao served on rice.

vocabulary.thai: ไข่ดาวด้วย
vocabulary.explanation: A classic addition to any 'raat khao' dish. ไข่ดาว (Kai dao) is 'fried egg', ด้วย (duay) means 'as well'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: กะเพราหมู (Krapao moo) ราดข้าว (raat khao), ไข่ดาวด้วย (kai dao duay - 'with a fried egg') ครับ (khrap). - Pad Krapao with pork on rice, with a fried egg too, please.

vocabulary.thai: กินมังสวิรัติ
vocabulary.explanation: The general term for vegetarianism (may include eggs/dairy).
vocabulary.example_sentence: ผม (Phom - 'I') กินมังสวิรัติ (gin mangsawirat - 'am vegetarian'). - I am vegetarian.
vocabulary.slang: กินเจ (Gin jay) is a stricter vegan (no garlic/onions) and is also widely understood.

vocabulary.explanation: A very important phrase for allergies. ฉัน (Chan) is 'I', แพ้ (pae) is 'to be allergic'. Follow it with the ingredient.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ฉัน (Chan - 'I') แพ้ (pae - 'am allergic to') ถั่ว (tua - 'peanuts'). - I am allergic to peanuts.

vocabulary.explanation: Used in 'Moo Bping' (Grilled Pork) or 'Khao Kha Moo' (Braised Pork Leg).
The star of 'Pad Krapao Moo Sap'.
Delicious fried pork belly, often eaten in 'Pad Kana Moo Grob'.
Used in 'Khao Man Gai' (Chicken Rice) or 'Gai Tort' (Fried Chicken).
Used in 'Guay Tiao Nuea' (Beef Noodle Soup).
Used in 'Khao Na Bpet' (Rice with Roast Duck).
The star of 'Tom Yum Goong'.
Used in 'Pla Pao' (Salt-Crusted Grilled Fish).
Literally 'ink fish'.
Literally 'sea', used for mixed seafood in dishes like 'Khao Pad Talay'.
Used for 'Kai Dao' (fried egg) or 'Kai Jiao' (omelette).
The main protein for many vegetarian dishes.
Standard steamed jasmine rice.

vocabulary.thai: ข้าวเหนียว
vocabulary.explanation: Eaten with hands, common in Isaan/Northern food.

vocabulary.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยว
vocabulary.explanation: The general term for noodle soup dishes.
The standard noodle for Pad Thai and boat noodles.
Used in 'Pad See Ew' and 'Rad Na'.
The general word for vegetable.
A common garnish; some people ask for it to be removed.
Common in noodle soups and Pad Thai.
Key ingredient for sourness.
A base flavor for almost everything.
The source of the heat.
The key herb in 'Pad Krapao'. Peppery and distinct from other basils.
Specifies plain drinking water.
Literally 'hard water'.
Can be 'kafae rorn' (hot) or 'kafae yen' (iced).
Common brands are Singha, Leo, and Chang.
Literally 'orange water'.

vocabulary.thai: น้ำมะพร้าว
vocabulary.explanation: Often served fresh in the coconut.

vocabulary.thai: น้ำผลไม้ปั่น
vocabulary.explanation: 'Naam ponlamai' is fruit juice, 'bpan' is blended.
e.g., Pad Thai, Pad See Ew.
e.g., Tom Yum, Tom Kha Gai.
e.g., Gai Yaang (Grilled Chicken).
e.g., Gai Tort (Fried Chicken).
e.g., Gaeng Khiao Waan (Green Curry).
e.g., Yam Woonsen (Glass Noodle Salad).
Less common for eating, but useful to know.
Borrowed from English.

vocabulary.thai: เครื่องปรุง
vocabulary.explanation: Refers to the set of condiments (sugar, chili, etc.) found on most tables.
The most common way to ask for the bill. It means 'calculate money'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: พี่ (Pee - 'staff') ครับ (khrap), คิดเงิน (kit ngern - 'check please'). - Excuse me, check please.
vocabulary.slang: เช็คบิล (Check bin) and เก็บตังค์ (Geb dtang) are also very common.

vocabulary.explanation: Essential for street food stalls without listed prices.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ทั้งหมด (Tang mot - 'altogether') เท่าไหร่ (tao rai - 'how much') ครับ (khrap)? - How much is it altogether?

vocabulary.explanation: A great compliment to give when paying. อร่อย (Aroy) is 'delicious', มาก (mak) is 'very'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: อร่อยมาก (Aroy mak - 'very delicious') ครับ (khrap), ขอบคุณ (khob khun - 'thank you'). - Very delicious, thank you!

vocabulary.explanation: A polite way to indicate you've finished. อิ่ม (Im) is 'full' and แล้ว (laew) means 'already'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: อาหาร (Ahaan - 'the food') อร่อย (aroy - 'delicious'), แต่ (dtae - 'but') อิ่มแล้ว (im laew - 'I'm full'). - The food was delicious, but I'm full now.

vocabulary.thai: ไม่ต้องทอน
vocabulary.explanation: A common and appreciated phrase. ไม่ต้อง (Mai dtong) means 'no need to', ทอน (torn) means 'give change'.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ไม่ต้องทอน (Mai dtong torn - 'keep the change') ครับ (khrap - polite particle). - Keep the change, thanks.

vocabulary.thai: ขอใบเสร็จด้วย
vocabulary.explanation: For those needing a receipt. ขอ (Kaw) is 'may I have', ใบเสร็จ (bai-set) is 'receipt', ด้วย (duay) makes it polite.
vocabulary.example_sentence: ขอใบเสร็จด้วย (Kaw bai-set duay - 'receipt, please') ครับ (khrap). - May I have a receipt, please?
